a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 0 & 4 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & -3 \\ 4 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -5 & -2 & -3 \\ -8 & 0 & -12 \\ 14 & 2 & -12 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 0 & 4 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & -3 \\ 4 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -5 & -2 & -3 \\ -8 & 0 & -12 \\ 14 & 2 & -12 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[1,1,-2],[0,4,-3],[-1,4,3]])"
and h1 : "B = matrix([[2,-2,0],[1,0,-3],[4,0,0]])"
shows  "(A ** B) = matrix([[-5,-2,-3],[-8,0,-12],[14,2,-12]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 4 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then -1 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 4 else 3)"
and h1 : "B = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then -2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 4 else 0)"
shows  "A ** B = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then -2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -8 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -12 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 14 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 2 else -12)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 0 & 4 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & -3 \\ 4 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -5 & -2 & -3 \\ -8 & 0 & -12 \\ 14 & 2 & -12 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & -2 \\ 0 & 4 & -3 \\ -1 & 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & -3 \\ 4 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -5 & -2 & -3 \\ -8 & 0 & -12 \\ 14 & 2 & -12 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 4 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then -1 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 4 else 3)"
and h1 : "B = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then -2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 4 else 0)"
shows  "A ** B = mat 3 3 (\<lambda> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then -2 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -3 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -8 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 0 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then -12 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 14 else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 2 else -12)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two 3x3 matrices A and B. Matrix A has elements {1, 1, -2; 0, 4, -3; -1, 4, 3} and Matrix B has elements {2, -2, 0; 1, 0, -3; 4, 0, 0}. What is the matrix product of A and B? The result is {-5, -2, -3; -8, 0, -12; 14, 2, -12}.

and the matrix B with elements:

    1st row: 2, -2, 0
    2nd row: 1, 0, -3
    3rd row: 4, 0, 0

The final answer is the matrix with elements:
